Remediation: Identify all metrics and ways they could be manipulated by different types of users; define additional requirements. Define logging requirements that capture sufficient information for thorough analysis of application activity contributing to each metric
Define test cases for OAT-016 Skewing that confirm the application will detect and/or prevent users attempting to skew metrics.

Consider randomising the content and URLs of metric-related content, tying these changes to the individual user’s session, verifying the changes at each request, and restricting any identified automated usage.
Consider identifying and restricting automated usage by fingerprinting the User Agent for its unique characteristics. Use the information to reject related metric contributions.

Consider identifying and restricting automated usage by reputation methods. In particular, consider using geolocation and/or IP address block lists and/or reputation services to exclude fraudulent data contributing to the metrics.
Consider requiring identity authentication, re-authentication or some other increased authentication assurance for access to areas where metric data are collected.

Consider adding delays to metric-contributing actions. Consider limiting the number of times and/or rate at which the activity of a session, and/or IP address, and/or account/user and/or device/fingerprint contributes to each metric. Consider enforcing single-use and a limited period of validity for metriccontributing one-time tokens/codes.

Log all activity contributing to metrics; monitor trends and abnormal patterns. Perform analysis, near real-time if possible, for common patterns in users’ system fingerprints, IP addresses and HTTP headers (such as User Agent, cookies, etc.), especially for requests during extremes of metric values.
Define end user T&Cs, employee contracts, corporate policies etc to ensure users understand that metric Skewing is not permissible.
Define actions to be taken in the event a Skewing attack is detected.
